We had the need for a device to hold a subjects head in one place firmly for eye tracking studies, but without the claustrophobic feeling associated with being unable to 'get out'. This clamp firmly holds the subjects head, but allows them the freedom to withdraw at any time. It is self centering, and is very well tolerated. It has thus far fit every head we have tried, from small children to "fat head adults".

This thing needs support to print correctly as there are significant overhangs. Print 2 brackets and mount with the shorter arms towards the middle.
This thing was modeled in TurboCAD 17.

Everyone knows the Standford Bunny. I printed it with voronoi pattern an then I thought it would be nice to have some baby bunnies for Easter...
I print the big one about 10 cm and the baby bunny about 5 cm tall.

My class and I came across a great idea on Thingiverse for a fidget ring:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:188275

We decided to try and design our own for students in our classroom. The mechanism for assembling ours is almost identical to the linked Thing, ours needs to be hammered together and is quite a tight fit (we were making them for High School students and wanted them to NEVER be able to come apart).

I don't know if this qualifies this as a remix then, but we never modified any files, just was inspired by the design.

The ring is quite large, as all the small rings we tested eventually caused my students to have their fingers get a little raw.

There are three spinners included, with the micro being my students favorite. All of ours were printed on Makerbot Replicator+ with either Makerbot PLA or ColorFabb PLA.

title: NERF Vulcan Tripod Magazine Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Do you need a simple, easy to use system to use almost any mag-fed NERF blaster with a Vulcan tripod? If so, this is the 3D print for you!

This is a magazine stand for a Nerf Vulcan tripod. Intended to allow placement of a blaster on the tripod with ease, this tripod stand opts to use the magazine, boasting a more central position, to hold the blaster. This means that the blaster is more evenly weighted front / rear across the tripod, increasing ease of use.

Currently, the magwell is a little tight. This means that using it as an easy on/off emplacement is difficult. I plan to upload a second model, with looser tolerances, to allow for use more as an emplacement. This second model will also include a drain hole, allowing use in more permanent outdoor wars (lookin' at you, Thunderdome).

Works with 12 dart clips. Should work with 18 dart clips, but is untested. Will work with a 6 dart clip, but the grip on the magazine is not that good. (who would have a gun emplacement with only 6 darts anyway)

Will NOT work with the 10 dart curved "banana" clips, and (obviously) any "drum" style magazines.

I do not run an Etsy or anything of the sort, but I could care less if you have it printed on MakeXYZ or perhaps 3dHubs. Just don't buy it from any of those drop-shipping eBay sellers.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

This model should print with no supports. 20% infill should be fine, although going higher can't hurt.
Designed in Fusion 360, super simple model. Sketch + extrude all from the main plane. Added filleting to allow for easier slotting of the magazine into the magwell.

print_settings.Notes:: I used 100% infill for the side bridge shapes. For the top and bottom parts I used 25% infill.

description.text: I'm in third grade and this is my science fair project. This is a bridge with removable sides that you can test how much weight it can hold for each shape. It has square, circle and triangle shapes. The strongest one was the triangle side bridge shape and the weakest one was the square side bridge shape.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Notes:

I used 100% infill for the side bridge shapes. For the top and bottom parts I used 25% infill.

I used cad software (cad stands for computer aided design) called Fusion 360. I made a sketch and some of the important tools I used were rectangles, dimensions to measure things, lines, and patterns to make copies of a shape. When I was done with everything I saved an .stl file so the slicer could read it.

Hypothesis

I think the triangle will hold the most weight because the pyramid is more stable than the cube, I know this because when I tried using sticks to make a cube it was all wobbly, and when I made a pyramid out of it it stood up straight and tall. Also, once when I saw a bridge there were triangles on the side.

Experiment

I put the bridge shapes in a slot on the side and then put the top on the bridge. I used 2.5 lb weights and one by one placed them on top of the bridge. When the weights crashed down on the sides it sounded like "THOOM!!" I also used bigger weights like 10 lb, 25 lb, 5 lb, and smaller 10 lb weights. Also I made a Google Sheet to record the data which you can see here. When the shapes held up I would click the check mark, When the shapes crashed down I would click an x.

Results

My hypothesis was correct, the triangles held the most weight, 117.5 lb The circles held 110 lb, and the square only held 70 lb.

Mettez la vitesse lente pour une meilleure résolution!!!

The perfect mod for visualising your extruder motor's movement!

This wheel magnetically attaches to the back of a nema 17 stepper motor. It requires two 2x1mm magnets. I recommend you superglue them, into the two slots on the top of the shaft. the slots are slightly large for the magnets (to leave room for error on low quality printers) but that shouldn't matter as long as you glue them in place well. Be careful with the superglue!

You might be wondering why I didn't make it so there is just one magnet that connects to the centre of the shaft. I did that because the actual shaft isn't magnetic. But the ring around it is - so they were the only place I could connect the magnets.

A video of it in action is here!!!! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qIqxJ6YP2oQ

description.text:
Designed for this tiny FPV camera: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LYAW6S6

...and tested to fit on the QX95 quadcopter stock frame.

I broke 2 previous FPV cameras for my QX95 by (1) hitting a brick wall, and (2) hitting the ground upside-down too many times which both broke the antenna off and caused the back of the camera to hit the frame and broke a tiny coil off.

This camera protector case is intended to prevent the camera from flopping backwards and hitting the frame, prevent it from being smashed if hit from the front (brick wall), and also protect the antenna with a stalk going up next to it.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kY4ILaOa7xN

title: Fidget Spinners
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yep! Another load of fidget spinners :-)
Designed in Fusion 360.
Sliced with S3D.
Printed on Prusa i3 MK2.
All the bearings are standard 608zz skateboard bearings (8x22x7mm)
The nuts are standard M10 (8mm thick)
The steel balls are 13mm and 8mm.
All the holes are designed to be a tolerance fit, meaning that they should fit with some persuasion. Depending on your printer or the precision of your components, if they don't fit tight, just add a small drop of CA glue (superglue)

description.text: To assemble, download and print the files above. For the button, print 2 copies of them. Take your 22mm (classic skateboard bearings) and align them with the holes. I recommend using a small hammer to gently hit the bearings in the holes (the fit should be tight). Finally, take the 2 button copies and slide them through the hole (on both sides) on the middle bearing. Same as bearings, you may need to apply lots of force or gently tap them with a hammer.

author: Nine9

description.text: The Infinity Garden is my personal version/derivation of the Kontinuum Garden designed by the Rasmussen brothers of Copenhagen, Denmark. You can read more about their awesome project, or help fund them at this address: http://www.indiegogo.com/Kontinuumgarden Personally, I thought their design could use a few tweaks, so I created this Thing as a Proof-of-Concept, and way to share my thoughts with them. I don't mean to steal any of their thunder, and welcome them to utilize any and all of my ideas shown here! The biggest improvement I have to offer is that everything in my design can be printed on a Makerbot Cupcake, Thing-O-Matic, or Replicator, thus encouraging maximum availability. My design was made in SolidWorks, and I've included a .zip file containing all of my original files, assemblies, renderings, etc. Feel free to experiment, modify, and create a neat Thing out of this! Again, this is a PROOF-OF-CONCEPT only, so I didn't check out dowel sizes at the hardware store, or figure out many of the minute details. So tweaking will be in order before anyone goes off printing this substantially print-intensive beast!

First let's briefly discuss the Rasmussen brothers' Kontinuum Garden, and what exaxtly it is/does. Long story short, it's a brilliantly simple hydroponic gardening system that utilizes the "Flood & Drain Sub-Irrigation" system. So each cell in the larger wheel contains a plant living in a hydroponic grow medium which is highly water-absorbant. The wheel turns (1 rotation per hour) slowly dipping the plants in the nutrient-rich water and then removing them. All the while, they are subjected to light from a central lighting source that provides much needed "sun" to all of the plants in the entire wheel. Now the brothers Rasmussen suggested a 4 step process:
  • Have/Build/buy a 3d printer.
  • Use it to build a gigantic 1 METER ^3 3d Printer.
  • Print the gigantic parts for their garden system.
  • Assemble it & Grow things.
    • I personally think step number 2 is unrealistic, unreasonable, and not remotely cost effective to the "Urban Gardening Hipster" they say they are appealing to with this invention. So my goal was to make a version of their design that could be printed on my Thing-O-Matic, and be supplimented with a few minor parts from the hardware store. Though this is very much a work in progress, I think it a success thus far. As you can see in the renderings, my hoops/wheels are constructed from 32 interlocking segments which are then supported by a series of metal or printed brackets. The screw that attaches these support brackets goes through the Wheel Segment, and into the pre-drilled end of the Wooden Dowel crossbars that make up the rest of the structure. The planter pods then slide onto said dowels, thus locking them into place and preventing them from falling out. The bottom of each plater pod has 7 holes allowing water to enter when submerged. Rather than having this giant wheel be toothed like a giant gear like they had designed, mine sits on two cross-bars in the watering tank. These are more wooden dowels suspended in bearings in the side of the tank, and covered by a piece of rubber tubing/hose for extra traction. One end of each of these "Drive Dowels" is fitted with a belt pulley, which will then be connected to a single motor mounted on the rear pillar to turn the entire contraption. I still have lots to add, including: --The motor & belt --The light bar --A resevoir tank for maintaining the water level --A simple control panel of some kind Cheers everyone! Will update soon! Message me with any questions, comments, hatemail, etc.

comments.text: I think the primary issue with a system like this is that the hydroponic solution seems to be permanently exposed to light? thus allow algae growth etc.

comments.text: Can the planter pots hang lower than the outside diameter of the wheel?  This would allow the water level to be below the wheel, thus keeping it dry (at least drier).
comments.author: chugadie

comments.text: Also...I think I can avoid the need for spokes by alternating every other planter pod by one post, thus making more of a "checkerboard" rather than multiple rows.  I.E. Assemble one complete circle.  Insert the dowels and attach the support brackets.  Then lay down a layer of planter pods, the start the next layer off by one dowel, and so on.
comments.author: L2NUB

comments.text: Why flip the plants upside down? Do a ferris wheel sort of thing and you could give them light from the top, or even natural light.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: You actually want to give the plants a variety of gradual stresses, as it builds stronger plants.  The plants orient themselves towards the greatest source of light, so you'd actually be denying them that by trying to keep their orientation correct.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: @cymon: Yep, RecoveringSalesman nailed it. Also, if the plants were kept rightside-up as it rotated like a ferris wheel, the plants could only be allowed to grow as tall as the distance to the next plant/crossbar. Otherwise they would interfere with their own rotation.
comments.author: RecoveringSalesman

comments.text: The more I look at this design......the more I think it will probably need 3 or 4 spokes on one or both sides to support all the weight of the plants and water.
comments.author: L2NUB

comments.text: Oh right.. the mechanics. A herringbone/gear-track integrated in the walls on each side would lower part count and a herringbone would also keep things centred.
comments.author: L2NUB

comments.text: Can you elaborate on this at all?  I don't quite follow what you're saying here.  My plan was to taper the "Drive Dowels", thus utilizing the same principles that keep a train on its tracks, as described here:
comments.author: danielpublic

comments.text: I think what daniel is talking about is turning the entire wheel into a giant gear wheel. By adding the gear teeth (herringbone style to prevent gear walking) to the ring it would allow you to better control the spped of rotation while reducing the vitamin count since the entire drive system is now printed instead of extra parts.
comments.author: L2NUB

comments.text: One could lower the growmedium/waterweight further by using materials such as Superabsorbent polymer(SAP)/sodium polyacrylate. Keeping the plants stationary with a net is easy and lightweight, especially if one roots the seedlings in the mentioned material and charcoal*/your average lightweight expanded claypellets. When SAP dries up it grasps whatever material nearby.
comments.author: L2NUB

comments.text: Thank you for the great info on Hydroponic grow mediums! :D  I'm always excited to learn new info about that.
comments.author: danielpublic

title: Anet A8 Dial Indicator Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Did this redesign for a friend. We ordered the 'Triton' dial indicator from Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B016R3GLB0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Only to find that there's a big lug protruding from the back of the dial. The lug prevented the dial from sliding into the original design, so I modified it by slotting the top of the design and closing in the sides to 'sandwich' the lug. I also had to increase the diameter of the indicator hole to 11mm in order to get the dial to fit.

The front of the holder was modified both to accomodate the dial (I added a deeper step down) and to allow the use of an M4 nut and an M4-16 bolt. Insert the nut into the pocket with one of the 'points' of the nut facing straight up.

Note that this design must be printed with supports.

print_settings.Notes:: Solid Layers:

description.text:
I recently switched to the Google WiFi mesh network because of some connection issues between my ASUS RT-AC3200 and certain smart-home devices (various connection / offline issues, etc). Additionally, while I've always loved the power of the RT-AC3200, it suffers the same issue of all routers, and I have almost no wifi at the front of the garage. I had used a cheap, bridged, ASUS modem to work around the problem, but it just didn't cut it. So, here I am with Google. #FingersCrossed that some of my problems are solved (and new ones don't develope).

Anyway, staying out of any other discussions on the matter, the Google WiFi, in my opinion, is a nice looking and minimalist device. It's wrapped LED is rather pretty and can communicate a lot. So, while the only other mount I could find on Thingiverse is amazingly put together (see joshdanielsjr's thing 2243674), it just covered the sides too much for what I wanted. So, here's my "minimalist" approach to a Google WiFI wall mount. I've tried to provide more than enough stability (don't what this falling off the wall during the "big one" out west), but I'm minimizing how much of the LED I'm covering. To the latter, I could probable get it down a bit more, but wanted to start with this first.

The only problem I have right now is, after hanging the Google WiFi up, I found that it doesn't actually have straight sides, but slightly angled. I've got my original up and working fine, but I'd like to revisit this and correct the side angles for a tighter fit going forward. I could just glue a cross bar, but think the original, support-less, design will still work with just that minor angling modification.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30% Rectilinear

Notes:

Solid Layers: 3x3x3 Top, Bottom, Side
Filament: spoolWorksPro Edge Grey06 1.75mm
Extruder / Bed Temperature: 240/80
Skirt: Single, five-outline, layer at 0.00mm

Carefully removed skirt and used standard drywall screws to attach. Google WiFi just slides in and wiring can be thru-wall with local electrical-code approved method. (Check for the appropriate codes for your area or don't run thru-wall wiring.)

Very careful using dimensional information from Google (Google WiFi Tech Specs) and old-fashion caliper measurements with my DCLR-0805 Electronic Digital Caliper. After that, there was some basic algebra and trigonometry to get a couple angles right and voila (hopefully).

title: Replicator 2 Dial Indicator Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Needed a slightly different design of the original. This version has a pocket to hold the nut in place (I'm not sure how the original stayed in place). It also has a larger hole for the dial indicator, it's 11mm now. This was necessary to accommodate the Triton dial indicator I purchased from Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B016R3GLB0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Note that the pocket for the nut runs upwards at a 30 degree angle, so you'll want to insert the nut into the pocket with the the flats of the nut parallel to horizontal. You should then be able to press it all the way down into the angled pocket.

remixed_from.author: cheer4ftc
remixed_from.title: Maze Cylinder Box - Visible and Hidden Versions

description.text:
A trick maze cylinder! The cylinder has an "entrance" and "exit" for the outer ring on the bottom and top respectively. The challenge is to feed the ring from bottom to top as fast as possible, or to remove the ring from the inner cylinder as fast as possible. Print a few copies and race with your friends! See the instructions to see how to make the trick version. Note that the non-trick version isn't very hard. If you want a challenging non-trick version that you can actually finish, try one of these:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207662 This is also customizable via the scad version. See the instructions in the scad file. The maze itself is pretty easy, because it's set up for the trick version. Inspired by:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207662
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13923
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34193

To make the "normal" version, just print the testNubRing.stl and the InsideNormal.stl files, and then feed the ring through.  
For the "trick" version, print the testNubRing.stl file first.  Then print the InsideTrick.stl file, but STOP IT HALF WAY THROUGH AND FEED THE RING ONTO THE INSIDE CYLINDER IN PART OF THE MAZE THAT HAS NO EXIT!  Then continue with the print.  You'll end up with a version where the ring cannot be removed.  Hand that one to your friend while you play with the normal one.  See how long it takes for them to figure out that there's no solution to their puzzle.  
It works best if you have 1 or 2 "normal" versions so the person with the trick one sees everyone else having no difficulty...

comments.text: ThomF, thanks for your make and your comment! I agree that the "standard" maze is quite easy as its purpose is to be easy in comparison to the trick version. If you want a more challenging maze without the trick, try printing the "hidden" version of this thing. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207662
comments.author: cheer4ftc

comments.text:
This is a neat design - but could be improved with a bit of tweaking. On the 'non-tricked' maze cylinder, it is pretty easy to move the ring from top to bottom. The paths line up too easily. I find that if you deviate from the easy path, you can get into some challenging positions.
My suggestion would be to make the starting path more difficult, which will add to the enjoyment of the game.
comments.author: ThomF

comments.text: ThomF, see my reply to your comment above.  I posted it before I realized I could post a direct reply to your comment.  Cheers.

title: Jabba the Hutt Cookie Cutter (Simple Version)

description.text:
This is a cookie cutter that I made from a drawing of mine. There are large and small versions, but I found that with the smaller version the dough would tend to get stuck in the face, so I can't really recommend it. With this kind of cookie cutter, you'll want to use some homemade dough rather than the stuff they sell in a tube (since that will lose all of the detail/shape when baked). I also recommend chilling the dough and using flour on the cutter and dough when cutting.

I also made another cartoony Jabba cookie cutter that I think it probably superior to this one, so be sure and check that out as well.

remixed_from.author: TimeFramed
remixed_from.title: Extrusion cooling fan holder/cowling for MakerFarm Prusa i3

title: Extrusion cooling fan-holder/cowling for MakerFarm Prusa i3 - Version 3

description.text: Update 12/7/2014

Uploaded two new versions of the .stl file:
  • Should be the same as the original, but only contains a single object (some slicers have issues with multiple objects in a singe .stl file).
  • Without "manual" support structure; it must be sliced/printed with support turned on. I wasn't real happy with the support that Slic3r generated for it; particularly under the large horizontal overhang; I think it should have printed support under the entire surface, but it only supported the edge, and gap-filled to make the surface...

After using my "version 2" fan holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:216229) for a while, I had two problems with it. First, it totally obstructed the view of the print head, making it difficult to monitor the first layer of a print. Second, the nozzle was a bit too small; it was so close to the extruder, that it deformed slightly from the heat. I had actually gone back to using my first cowling (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213416) with the second version's mounting parts.

This 60mm x 60mm x 10mm fan holder/cowling is designed to replace the left side-piece of the X carriage (see pictures). This fan holder and cowling has that part integrated into the design.  
It has no adjustments for position (that should really be a fixed location, dictated by the carriage and extruder), and holds the fan more rigidly than my previous designs.

WARNING:

  • There is not much clearance between the fan/cowling and the left-side X motor mount. Make sure the screw heads are facing the front, and the nuts are in back. If they're the other way around, the fan will hit the screw tips when the X carriage gets near the left edge of the print area before reaching the edge of the print area. (see photos)

    • When the screws in the X motor mount are oriented with the nuts in back, it will be close, but it will clear, and the X carriage will be able to move all the way to the left until it hits the X motor mount/Z rod holder.

Print without support.  The support required for the large horizontal overhang is part of the design, and is easily removed from the completed print.  
Remove the left side-piece from the X carriage, and replace it with this part, using the original nut and screw.  
Then attach the fan.  
The tip may appear to be a bit too far forward; that's intentional because the airflow tends to be towards the back, even though the opening is parallel to the X axis due to the shape of the cone.

Hey guys, here is my first thing! I hope someone actually tries to print it! Hopefully I'll have many more things to come!

This is a cool illusion mirror that work with a LED strip in betwen two half-reflecting mirrors.

Things you need:

  • A picture frame (I use RIBBA 50x40cm from IKEA)
  • A glass pane of the same size (or just buy another RIBBA)
  • A LED Strip (I recommend one with 60 LEDs/m)
  • One Way mirror tint film to cover both glass panes (better have some more if it doesn't work at the first time)
  • If you want to darken your mirror, you'll need some car window tinting film
  • 3d printed spacers
  • do yourself a favor and work in a dust-free environment

Tools you need

  • A sharp cutter knife
  • A doctor blade (is usually delivered with films)
  • A spray can with soapy water
  • Some hot glue

Instructions

Step 1

Take your frame and remove the back cover and glass.

Step 2

Cut films to size, one to two millimeters smaller than glass.

Step 3

Clean glass. Then spray with soapy water so that the pane is really wet. Carefully remove the protecting film from your mirror film and apply to both panes. With the doctor blade, remove all air bubbles.

Step 4

Install first mirror glass back to your frame, then apply the spacers with double-sided adhesive tape. You may want to install the last piece after the LED Strip.

Step 5

Install LED Strip.

Step 6

After checking your LED Strip and cleaning the glass (you'll see every dust particle later), install the second mirror. There should be enough space between mirror and picture frame to put the cables through.

Step 7

Install back cover and glue to frame with hot glue.

Step 8

Switch on your LED Strip and admire your self-made decoration!

remixed_from.title: CCG deck box with geared pivoting lid

title: Non-warping complex deck box with spring

description.text: I wanted to make belrius's deck box, but I don't have a heated platform so some of the flat plate-like parts wouldn't work for me. Thus, I made triangular holes in the parts, and they printed with minimal warp. I also included a spring to make the opening mechanism more snappy.

See Belrius's instructions. Stick the extra axle part (circle.stl) in the framework of the inner wall (holey_side.stl), and insert the "half gear" (half_gear.stl) onto the axle. Take a typical tension spring like from inside a pen or something and bend part of it into a loop with a ~3/4" straight section so it looks a bit like this:  
o----'VVVV|  
Hook the round part over the peg in the half gear, and stretch the spring-like part down and under the inner wall panel (holey_side.stl). Lock the spring in by snapping on the bottom panel. The gear is not held in well at this stage. After putting on the outer wall panel (holey_frontback.stl) the gear should stay in and not fly out when you try to open or close the box. I used CA glue for a more permanent solution, even though some of the parts snap together quite well.  
Printed on an ultimaker, btw.

title: Wine glass charms set with a box

description.text:
This is a set of 26 alphabet wine glass charms, with a box to hold them in. The charms should be printed without supports, the two arms of the spring clip cross each other, but should be no problem for bridging (I did not change any settings from defaults for my Prusa i3 Mk2).

If you want to print all 26 at once, there is the A-Z STL file where they are all arranged to fit on the printer bed. You can print the individual ones from the STL files with the corresponding letter in the name. It took me about 6 hours to print all 26 charms at once, or 16-20 minutes per charm if printed separately.

There is also a blank charm, just the spring clip and the ring, you can use it to fit in any object or text of similar size.

The box and the lid can be printed together. The lid is fitted pretty tightly but easy enough to pry open. I printed everything from PLA.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm (charms), 0.35mm (box)

Infill:

concentric or none

Notes:

Charms don't really have infill (there may be few layers inside the little spheres, any infill will do). For the box, either increase the number of vertical shells so you don't need infill, or set concentric infill.

This is a generic lightsaber that can be used for anything you want! I would recommend printing the handle in silver/black or stainless steel filament and the bolt in whatever color you want. A future revision will follow with support for a LED in the hilt for clear bolts. It is about .75 inches in diameter at the thickest part, and 12.5 inches long.

The center module is wrapped in LEDs around the cylinder. The Arduino is housed in the casing below, and this housing has several entrances: one for the power cables for the Arduino and LEDs, one for a button, one for the LEDs to connect to the Arduino, and one for the microphone.
The base plate has a specific housing for the Arduino meant to keep it from moving once the box is the plate is glued to the bottom of the center module.
The diffuser screen is simply meant to be placed on top of the center cylinder module, such that it lays flush with the top of the cylinder.

author: wesrigler

title: Enclosure for a Thinkpenguin USB WiFi adapter

description.text:
An alternative multi-purpose case for the Thinkpenguin TPE-N150 USB
Wifi network adapter (this: https://www.thinkpenguin.com/gnu-linux/penguin-wireless-n-usb-adapter-w-external-antenna-gnu-linux-tpe-n150usbl)

This is a low-profile snap-together enclosure, designed to be more portable
than the original case.

The enclosure consists of three separate parts:

  • Top cover
  • Bottom cover
  • Table-top / desk stand with room for weights

The top and bottom cover snap together, with the PCB sandwiched in between.
It's a very snug fit; take care when you assemble it, or you'll break the case.

The lower part snaps vertically over the top, and the top snaps horizontally
around the lower. The top has columns to lock the PCB and lower cover into
place, and these can be difficult to fit through the holes.

The desk stand is optional, and snaps onto the enclosure. There is room for
adding a weight, so that the thing doesn't topple over so easily.

A somewhat accurate mockup of the PCB is included in the blender file.

The thickness of the top and bottom is only 0.8mm, which makes it flexible.
This flex is possibly required for the case to fit.
I suggest you increase the thickness if you want a sturdier case, but if you
do, you may have to increase the snap-height by ~.5 - 1mm. Note that,
depending on the orientation you print in, the thinner parts may be prone
to splitting or snapping, especially with PLA.

I've made this model for my immediate needs, and it's unpolished.
Please improve it and modify it for your own needs!

Notes:

  • Blender and STL files are included
  • Successfully printed using
    • PLA (210C, 70C hotbed)
    • 10% infill (doesn't matter really)
    • 0.30mm layer height
    • 1.0mm shell thickness
    • I suggest using supports for the overhangs, but it's not required
      (I didn't have any)
  • I use velcro to attach the cover to my laptop

author: Piglet

description.text: If you happen to have 4, 8, 12 or more Intel Galileo devices you can assemble them into a big tower. This design allows you to see all the boards and blinking lights while holding them tightly together. All of the network cables and power goes thru the center of the tower so you get a clean view of the boards and excellent cable management. You can then use Meshcentral.com to remotely manage all of the devices over the Internet and use Arduino Mesh management tools to push sketches easily. Included a part file will print 6 corner parts in one pass, another file with 4 top parts and the STL and Blender files. Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQMKWrHOg4k. The original tower at 16 Intel Galileo devices, but we now added 3 more layers for 28. Also, I can confirm that this same part will work with the Galileo 2. The Galileo 2 is longer but the same width, so as long as you have all the same boards of the same type, you just get a different size tower.

We looked at many different ways to arrange Intel Galileo devices into a big arranged array. Because of how the power and network connectors are arranged there is no good way to line them up. The best way we found it to form them into a circle of 4 and stack them. It also looks nice and manages the cables very well.
I provided files for 6 corner parts and another file with 4 top parts. On the Replicator 2X that we have at 40% file it took about 9 hours to print the 6 parts file at medium quality.

comments.text: What do you even do with that many boards?
comments.author: pwnate

comments.text: Normally, you don't have a bunch of them grouped up in a tower like this. You connect them to sensors and put them all over a building and site. Since I work on developing http://Meshcentral.comMeshcentral.com, I need to test the software and so, this is one of my options. At the same time, it's a great art piece and draws a lot of attention. Just added 3 more layers to it for a total of 28. I still have room in the center for more cables, but probably not many more.
comments.author: pwnate

description.text:
UPDATED:

I've changed this so that it now includes 2 bearings. The single bearing version worked, until the filament wore a groove and then started to jam. This new 2 bearing version works really well and is jam free. Also now includes a base for easy securing and better rotation.

This is V2 of a rotating filament guide, that was designed to be used with grooved bearing I purchased from 'Banggood' = https://www.banggood.com/624VV-V-Groove-Sealed-Ball-Bearings-Vgroove-4x13x6mm-17mm-Deep-p-931400.html?rmmds=myorder

You'll need to print off 4 x washers as well (one either side of each bearing). The screw to hold the filament guide goes under the bearing, so install that first. Leave it loose enough to be able to rotate.

The screw I used (well, bolts actually) are shown here (you'll need 2 per filament holder):- http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/221307549544?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=520187426971&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

The filament in the photo is 1.75mm, so hopefully that will give you an idea of the size of the guide.

description.text: I saw the octopus and its predecessors and thought it would be cool to make. I loaded the single tentacle into 3D Builder in Win10 and noticed that it wasn't laying flat on what would be the build plate so I attempted to make my own raft material object and saved that, then applied it to the tentacle object. I modified the raft object in an attempt to avoid mashing it in with the joint areas while still supporting the underside of the tentacle. at this point (04.29.17) I have not printed it yet but I thought I would offer this model if anyone has had problems with their prints stringing out in mid air. I got the rafting idea from the Crocz object, aka the alligator clip which has rafting material built into the model, with little effort peels away from the build. Also using this rafting method reduces warping during the print process in most cases.

Printer:

XYZPrinting Da Vinci Jr 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

no auto-rafting in print settings, the raft is in the model.

comments.text: I should also note that this is my first contribution to thingiverse. been collecting things and printing for about a year and recently I finally got a windows 10 machine I can use a 3d editor with my xyzprinting slicer software. a little bit ago I tried to feed the model to my da vinci jr via Build from Card option but it said that filetype wasn't supported.. but it should be since I exported the model to davinci's file type prior. anyways if you make one please leave a comment about how it came out and if the raft peels off easy enough, if the joints are ok. may need a bit of trimming with the exact-o .

remixed_from.author: Mr_MegaTronic
remixed_from.title: VEND - the totally printed candy dispenser

description.text:
This is a remixed version of the vending machine that combines some parts of the original version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45347
and some parts of the remixed version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:250000

The reason for this remix is to take benefit of the best parts of each version and adding some modifications in order to have an european version that works with 0,50€ coins as the EuroBodyMachine.stl model shows.

The previous remixed version contains some improved parts such as the CoinCam and the lockers that really improves the functionality of the design. However, it makes the vending machine work by twisting the knob 180º instead of the original 360º each time the user inserts a coin. I modified the CoinCam.stl file to keep the functionality with the lockers, but allowing the 360º as the original vending machine.

As I do not like to have so many amount of candies every time I use the vending machine, I included this drum that is 60% smaller than the original one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:83741/#files

I checked that the quarter coin is so similar to the 0.50€ coin that the vending machine works perfectly. This is the reason why I have modified the body vending machine to indicate the use of this coin.

You can check the coin mechanism in the following video: https://youtu.be/MRKTmpMsbvE

TIPS AND ADVICES:
All parts have been printed with 0.2mm heigh, 20% infill, 60mm/s speed and 0.4mm nozzle. Supports are not needed for any piece.

I made an exception with the infill parameter printing Flap, because I liked the version with no coins (check previous remixed version if you like the other one). To avoid problems I printed it with 50% infill to increase his own weight

EuroBodyMachine.stl and Hatch.stl are huge models that takes a lot amount of time for printing. I changed my 0.4mm nozzle for a 0.8mm nozzle and I used 0.4mm heigh to reduce the printing time. Keep in mind that this option will reduce a little bit the quality and that you musth change the accurate parameters to slice the model before printing it (height, nozzle diameter, top and bottom amount of layers, shell thickness...).
As the body machine does not have too many details this might be a good option to save time. It is up to you ;)

Thanks to Mr_MegaTronic and MakerBobDesigns that built the originals.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For Flap use 50% infill.

Optional for Body and Hatch use 0.8mm nozzle with 0.4mm Resoultion. Save time, but reduce quality and need to change slicer parameters.
This Is a soldier I modeled a year or two ago. Never tested. Highly recommend green or tan filament.

title: Raspberry Pi Zero W Camera Mount

description.text:
A simple ball & socket articulated mount system designed to be used with medium size 3M Command Strips. Although the plate looks smaller than the Command Strip, it is designed to fit the adhesive area of the "red" side (not "wall" side) of the strip.

System was designed to provide a clean way to mount the new Raspberry Pi Zero W in it's new case as a camera. Sockets place enough tension on the joints to support a Raspberry Pi Zero's weight, but not a whole lot more.

Socket plate includes a small cable holder.

comments.text: The ball and socket are modeled at the exact same size. This gave good tension with the margin of error in my printer and print settings. If your printer is super calibrated or under-extruding then you may have more play in the joint than desired. If so, feel free to scale up the ball arms ever so slightly to 1.02 or 1.05 to add an extra 0.2mm or 0.5mm respectively to the diameter of the balls.

description.text:
I use my old RPi as an OctoPrint server. Added vents to let it breathe. I like how sturdy this case is.

Did have to sand some parts to make fit, but I just put it on carefully. Bolts down great to the outside of my enclosure.

I also wire-tied a 10mm 5v fan (threaded through the vents) to blow air in. The fan is held in place by wire ties.

The power is connected to the RPi’s pin 4 and 6, so if it is on, it is getting cooled.

Notice: I include the Sketchup files for my posts to allow modding and any changes you want made. I generally do not take pictures of my creations and only show the isometric view from Sketchup, as each print will be different.

Happy printing and modding!

Printer:

Prusa i3 Clone (Anet A8)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

5% (for speed)

Notes:

I printed mine in ABS. Won't take much heat or stress, so just don't use NinjaFlex ;)

Sketchup file included - happy modding!

This OpenSCAD program creates a user definable sized calibration cube.

  • The X, Y, and Z axis are user definably labeled.
  • Size is printed on one side. The calibration cube supports both metric and imperial/SAE units of measure.
  • Infill Percentage is printed on one side. The Infill Percentage is only included on the calibration cube for reference. The infill percentage is set in the slicer.
  • Due to OpenSCAD font limitations the font will get smaller in relation to the overall size once 380" is exceeded.

Modify the parameters as you like to customize your Calibration Cube.
When everything looks good click "Create Thing" to create the .STL.

Note: The Size sliding scale covers a large range. Use the mouse to get close then use the up/down arrows to fine tune.

I'm not including any wiring instructions as I am not an electrician. I searched how to wire two lights to one switch and kept searching till I felt confident enough. If you don't know what you are doing then don't do it. I am not responsible if you get shocked or any other bad thing that might happen. With that out of the way the wiring is super simple.

Printed without support and 0% infill. Models uploaded in correct orientation for printing.

LampTopBottomWhite - Print 2 I had the best luck printing separately

LampMidAnyColor - Print 1 I printed in black

CenterInsertAnyColor- Print 1 This slides into LampMidAnyColor and holds the bulbs and wiring

Parts needed in one Kit
Candelabra Base x2 - I cut the roller switches out and used just the clip in bulb sockets and one plug end. The rest of the wiring was done with the second cord.

Rocker switch 16a 125v - I like using these because they mount clean... and I had one laying around

Bulbs - Use E12 LED lights to cut down on heat and I wouldn't go any higher than 40 Watt equivalent.

Other things spade connectors, wire nuts, heat shrink, electrical tape, etc

Again - I'm not including any wiring instructions as I am not an electrician. I searched how to wire two lights to one switch and went from there. If you don't know what you are doing then don't do it. I am not responsible if you get shocked or any other bad thing that might happen.

title: Tevo Tarantula Control Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The control boxes on Thingiverse for the Tevo Tarantula were all too big and tried to incorporate everything into one case. I like the power supply sitting there all naked, and I'd already designed a case for the MOSFET expansion board so I didn't need room for that either. This case is designed to house the original mainboard, the control panel, a 6015 fan, a 6x2 barrier strip and a Raspberry Pi Model B Revision 2.

The Pi is mounted by itself, upside down on the top plate, so if you need a different model Pi, that would be an easy enough piece to customize. The back plate has holes for the USB connectors on both the mainboard as well as the Pi. This allows easy connection of a USB wireless dongle to the Pi. You connect the Pi and the mainboard with a short USB cable externally, making it easy to connect a computer to the mainboard for firmware updates. There are also holes for inserting the various input/output connections to the board. On the left hand side is a football shaped cutout to aid in accessing the SD card. On the right side, the fan is covered with a web-style grill to fit in with the Tarantula theme. The front panel features a grill for air circulation. I have my fan sucking air out, but you can blow air inwards if you prefer.

One thing to note... the Pi is already a tight fit. To get the power connector to fit, I had to trim the plastic away almost to the metal connector. If you have access to a 90° adapter, that might work better. Or solder the power wires directly to the Pi? Currently, my Pi is running off an AC power adapter, but if I can find/design a regulated 12vdc-5vdc converter, I plan on powering the Pi internally from the main power supply.

To put this together, you will need:

3mmx5mm screws x32
4mmx25 screws x4
4mm nuts x4
4 washers x8
6x2 barrier strip x1 (optional)

UPDATE

As per request, I have added a back panel and a top panel set up for a Raspberry Pi 3. I do not have this version of the Pi, so this was created using http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2106235 as a model. If you print this, and it works, please post an [I Made One] so I can see it. If it doesn't work... oh well... no, no, no... I'm kidding. Just let me know what needs to be modified so that it will work and I'll fix it.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This was designed to fit, one piece at a time, on a Tarantula with the standard bed. When printing, just rotate each piece until it is flat against the bed. No supports will be necessary.
This was designed in Sketchup 2014. As per request, I have uploaded the original case_h.skp model file for modifications. If you are just printing this, you can ignore that file.

comments.text: I did, yes. The z-limit switch and the fans I had already extended long enough when I first built the Tarantula, so those were already good for me. The hot end and the x-axis motor did have to be extended a bit. The x-axis isn't so big a deal, just cut the wires in half and splice in a longer wire in between the two halves making sure to insulate the connections with tape or (better still) heat shrink tubing. For the hot end, though, you need to make sure that you use heavy enough wire and make sure that you keep it as short as possible while still getting the job done. You will also want to be triple sure of the solder connections between the wires and, again, use heat shrink tubing (or tape) to insulate the connections. I think I had to extend mine about six to eight inches and I have not had any problem at all, even with my last print which was a 235° ABS print that wne ton for right at 24 hours.

description.text:
I saw the Holster Runkel made and thought I should make one for the best box cutter I ever owned... The Stanley Fat Max
The way the Holster is made you don't really need the Magnets but for safety reasons I added them anyway.
You'll need 5x10mm N45 Neodym Magnets

I made the slots no the Blade can never be so long that you can cut your self as the box cutter is attached to the Holster but you can cut taped shut boxes right away since the Blade is peaking out a few mm, as seen in the third and forth Picture ;)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Various 0.15-0.30mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

I bumped up the Layerhight to 0.3mm for most of the print, I graduatly got it down to 0.15 around the holes for the Magnets and the Beltloop overhang

Print duration~1h45-2h
Print it upright so there is no need for Support
Glue in the 5mm by 10mm Neodym N45 Magnets so they stick out a tiny bit and will always touch the side of the Blade

title: EDGE - A Snap Together Fidget Spinner

description.text: This spinner uses 3 22mm bearings, 2 of them fit in the spaces inside the spinner. After you position those first two, snap on the top of the spinner, and fit the middle bearing into the center hole. Now you can pop the caps in. It may be tempting to hammer the caps in, but don't because it could cause the first layer to peel off. Finally, make sure the caps are flush with the top and bottom of the spinner. Enjoy!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If you plan on using wood filament or any other filament that can be stringy, there will be some extra clean up so that the bearings will fit.

description.text:
I preferred to have the bottom-end of my Anet A6 power supply uncovered in case I needed to make any adjustments in the future or add more lights, so I made this case for the power supply fuse and switch. I borrowed the schematic for the mounting holes from the link below. It also details VERY well how to wire up the switch so I no longer had that big pop every time I plugged in the printer.

http://www.instructables.com/id/Wire-Up-a-Fused-AC-Male-Power-Socket/

EDIT: Added V2 file that adds another mounting hole and moves the holes further away from the module to allow for drilling into the base without needing to screw in at an angle.

Anet A6

Yes

0.2

25%

description.text:
sick of fiddling about trying to get my scope out of the flight carry case I had a kerching idea moment, why not design a handle that would attach to the bolts that are on the top of the skywatcher 120p scope rings. so the idea was born and after 30 mins I had a handle printing.

This is designed and sized to fit on the scope rings of my 120p. all I needed to do was buy 2 bolts (standard camera mount thread size 1/4 inch 20 tpi (threads per inch).Depending on how long the bolts are your have or buy you may need to cut them down to size. Unscrew the lonley single bolt and push the new bolts trough the 2 holes in the handle and tighten down. Nice and easy. make sure the bolts are long enough to tighten down into the threaded holes and not too long to go right through and into the telescope tube

This may fit other scope rings and scopes I do not know...

Printer:

CTC Rep dual Sailfished

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20 / 0.25

Infill:

15-25 %.. I use 15%

Notes:

Print this on its side and it should be a straight forward print without the need for supports etc.

author: babar121

description.text:
Small Fidget Spinner for little kids. This was about as small as I could make it without it being to fragile.

22mm bearing for the middle: http://amzn.to/2pvjFKH

I glue six dimes in the outside with super glue and kicker. http://amzn.to/2qiJ655

LED Illumination MOD for the Anet A8.
You don't need to print anything!

I'm always trying to get the best result with minimal effort, and this is the perfect example. On Thingiverse you can find some structures made for support leds for your printer.. but are they really needed?
Led strips have an adhesive layer on its back, and the small 3528 leds are mounted on an 8 mm wide strip that is exactly the width of the Anet acrylic frame.

I used 3528 led strips to illuminate my Anet A8 while printing. I also added a small led strip chunk under the extruder assembly to have a brighter view of the current printing job.
This is controlled by OctoPrint and a 2-relay board, but you can simply use a rocker switch getting power from the power supply.

Video showing how it works: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rMFnYT3vU9w

Info on how to use a relay board with OctoPrint: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1428478

Check out all my Anet A8 projects:

  • Anet A8 Prusa i3 Simple filament guide (Horizontal) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764285
  • Anet A8 RPi Camera Bed mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1867549
  • Anet A8 Y Axis Cable Chain v2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1915486
  • Anet A8 hotbed thermal insulation http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1917197
  • Anet A8 Power supply cover w\LCD power meter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2087761
  • Anet A8 Z-Axis RPi Camera mount for panning timelapses http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2265949
  • Anet A8 LED Illumination MOD http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2285674
  • The One - Anet A8 - Universal Spool Holder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2456038

What you need
  • 1m 3528 led strip (perferably waterproof, but not mandatory)
  • 1m red\black thin wires (actually any color is ok, but I like to keep it consistent)
  • 30 cm red\black wires (a bit thicker)
  • heat shrink tubing (optional but recommended)
  • (if using OctoPrint) 2-channel relay board like this one http://www.gearbest.com/power/pp_348958.html
  • (if not using OctoPrint) a rocker switch of your choice
Installation

1) Cut the led strip in chunks as follow:

  • 2x 30 cm
  • 1x 25 cm
  • 1x 5 cm
    (you will also have a spare 10 cm strip for some other projects)

2) Cut the 1m wire in chunks as follow:

  • 1x 75 cm
  • 2x 10 cm
  • 1x 3 cm

2) Solder wires and led strips as follow:

  • extruder assembly: 75 cm wire -> 5 cm led strip
  • left frame: 10 cm wire -> 30 cm led strip
  • top and right frame: 10 cm wire -> 25 cm led strip -> 30 cm led strip (see picture)
    Use heat shrink tubes to protect solder points.

Since 3528 led strips and the Anet frame are both 8mm wide, you don't need to print anything: simply use the strip adhesive back to place the chunks in place. See pictures to correctly place the one under the extruder assembly and the top-right angle.
You can use the existing cable organizer to carry the wire from the extruder assembly to the top of the frame.

Once placed, you should have all wires behind the top left angle of the frame. Carry power there from the relay board using the thicker 30 cm wire chunk. Connect all red wires together and all black wires together with the method you prefer (I used those transparent screw caps)

If you aren't using OctoPrint, carry the power directly from the power supply or from the main board power wires, putting a rocker switch in between.

The extruder assembly light Don't forget the heat shrink tube! Strip for the left frame (at the top) and the top-left one (bottom) Place the 5 cm led strip under the extruder assembly, near the screw Use the existing cable organizer for the led strip wire Led strips on left-top-right frame Angle detail (out of focus, sorry) Where all wires come together (out of focus again :-\) Go through the hole to have that stuff out of sight My setup with a Raspberry Pi 3 B for OctoPrint, a 2-channel relay board and 2 MOSFETs All the mess hidden :D Here is how it works

title: Sewing, craft or shop expanding box

description.text:
This is a remix of the Sewing box by NicApicella. It addresses the issues raised in the original in terms of sizing and adds a top as well as patterns for a felt lining.

Text in light blue (cyan) in the files should be deleted or ignored when cutting. They are instructional only. There are 3 holes in the Sewing Box Boxes file that are used to size the holes you'll need. The files have 5mm holes for 1/4" Chicago Screws sourced from Amazon. They have a slightly smaller diameter barrel and fit snugly but not overly tight. The 3 holes (in green) are 0.2", 5mm and 4mm for common Chicago Screw diameters for 1/4" long screws. Cut these first and then adjust the files if needed and then delete or ignore the green holes.

The holes in the sides are colored red. These may need to be resized if Chicago Screws with a different diameter are used. They should be cut first from the material so their alignment is true when the larger piece's outline is cut.

Self-adhesive felt from craft stores like Michaels works well if using this for a jewelry box or other storage where the contents need to be protected from the wood.

This is sized for 1/8" nominal (3mm) Baltic Birch plywood.

The box is 26" long when fully opened. When closed it is 9.5" long X 4.75" wide X 5" tall.

Printer:

Glowforge Laser Cutter

No

Supports:

No

description.text:
I have always thought that the holocrons within Star Wars looked really cool, and the information that they hold makes them even more awesome!

I have created a few different versions of the holocron depending on what you want to use it for:

  • A completed holocron with the corners in line with the rest.
  • A completed holocron with the corners turned as when the jedi are opening the holocron.
  • A holocron with the corners off.
  • A holocron that has no corners as well, but has pegs sticking out with a small tab on the pegs where the corners would go (the "jedi holocron base" file). Which I have also included the corners separate with the holes for the pegs with a slot for the tabs to fit into so you can attach the corners and spin them around.

Depending on your printer and the settings you are using, you might need to use support for the overhand on some of the parts.

May the mass time acceleration be with you!!

title: iPad Air Sound Deflector Air Bender

description.text:
I modified the design by Archimiedies.

  1. Wanted the sound bender to be much lower profile and not stick out so far and get caught on things so I shortened it a bit.
  2. Wanted it to fit more snug. iPad air is 9.7mm think. Modified sound bender to be 9.65mm between the fingers. Fits much more snug and the thicker fingers are stronger
  3. Wanted the sound bender to be rounded to focus sound more straight out rather than some sound being deflect off on an angle. Can't quantify how much more directional the sound is but comparing the two side by side it sounds better to me with the rounded feature. The rounded feature alone allows the unit to be lower profile.
    • I'm including the gcode file as well which has all the appropriate supports.

-Included a pic showing the original and mine side by side to compare the size profile. lighter blue original, darker blue my remix.

UPDATE - Made another revision. I extended the length of the fingers and adjacent backing to have more surface area gripping onto the ipad. Even more snug now. Also angle the fingers and backing instead of rounded...better profiling as to reduce snagging on anything.
Uploaded the gcode with supports for this one too.

print_settings.Notes:: Print these flat, NOT vertical. The point of the halves is to give the pegs tension strength.

description.text:
Print these flat, NOT vertical. The point of the halves is to give the pegs tension strength.

This is a two piece peg designed to hold together the components of a rubik's cube core. You will need two halves per peg. The washer holds the two halves together and provides a smooth surface to reduce spinning friction/catching.

There is a short and long version of the peg. You may need to trim the length after printing depending on the core you are using. I used short pegs for five sides, and a trimmed long for the sixth side to allow easier assembly.

The pegs can be glued into the core, or in my case they were a pressure fit.

Notes:

print_settings.Notes:: I printed with a brim.

description.text:
I dropped and smashed the glass bowl lampshade for the FC8T9/CW 22W 4100K T9 Circline fluorescent torus bulb. I made a new one.

I designed it in OpenSCAD, and the OpenSCAD makes it easy to render the whole thing, or just a segment.

I had to make it in segment and superglue it together because my printer is very small. After I made two 1/12 pieces, I discovered that a 1/6 piece would fit.

The OpenSCAD file would make a good customizer, but it's more flexible than that. You can customize the size, the number of polygons in the approximation of the partial sphere, how the sphere is cut, how thick the shell is, etc.

Printer:

Monorice Mini Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.13m

Infill:

6%

Notes:

Shell thickness 0.8
translucent PLA

As I brought each piece into Cura, I rotated it about the vertical axis to the piece was aligned on the diagonal to make it fit the print bed.

I printed with a brim.

I left the inside of the brim intact - it adds a bit of stiffness, and breaks up the light if the seams don't quite match all the way along the mating pieces.

I glued the 6 PLA pieces together with cyanoacrylate glue (superglue is the leading brand), and drilled three small holes in the perimeter.

I drilled three holes in the metal fixture, added self-tapping sheet metal screws, and suspended the new shade from a paperclip on each screw,

This makes me so happy.

I had an idea. I wrote down a few equations in a text file with a .scad extension, ran that through OpenSCAD to get a .stl file, then Cura to get a .gcode, and set the printer going. In a few hours I had a new lampshade.

From my mind to reality in just a few minutes work, and a few hours of time waiting for the printer.
the one ring spinner

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4SeTt0iEDK5
Fits cutout in the side of the Makerbot Replicator 2

I originally created this 3d file about 12 years ago for an old PC game project called GL_Tron.  When I received my Thing-O-Matic last summer, this model kit is one of the first projects I thought about creating.  After many hours modifing the original model it's finally it's done!
EDIT:  I have now included individual part files per request.

I have included an illustrated instruction manual to help guide you in assembling this kit, but here are few notes to help get you started.
All of these parts have printed very successfully for me without rafts or support.  The one place on the front wheel that needs support, has it built into the STL file.  After printing you just trim off the small support wall.
This kit also uses 3mm pins to align parts. Because I am still printing with 3mm filament, I just cut short 6mm long sections to use as pins. If you have a Replicator, or print with 1.75mm filament, I have provided a file to print a set of pins.
The parts for this model are separated into groups by color to replicate the design of the movie Lightcycle.  The frame and wheel hubs should be gray, the windows and wheel covers black, and the wheels and body another color like blue or red for example.  Of course, there are no rules.

comments.text:
GL_Tron was one of my favorite games to play with friends during my lunch hour in High school.

An Eldar Vyper skimmer bike proxy for Epic Armageddon

Super glue to assemble.

was a remodel of the dark eldar venom. the venom is more concave where as the vyper is more convex. the eldar model is slightly narrower (wings) as well.

the bike formations can substitute any number of 'regular' jet bikes for vypers. fun stuff.

I am not going to be running a body on my Traxxas Slash anymore as it gets to much air in the body when going at speeds. I dont want to grind the posts off for holding the body when flipping over, so i designed these to be slid on and screwed into where the posts do. These should wear down instead of body mount holders and prevent other parts from being damaged when flipped on the lid.

I plan on mounting a VG racing roll cage and some lexan body panels to give it a body latter on, these are just temporary. I will probably be designing a roof skid plate for the roll cage when it arrives.

I have created 3 fidget spinners with 3, 4 and 5 planets each. They have the same bumpy design to have no sharp edges and yet provide grip and visual interest.

print_settings.Notes:: Designed to be printed with no supports, and on a small printer. It should be able to fit in most printers. I had the "Crest with spikes" print fail once because of a lack of bed adhesion (in the last 10 minutes, I'm not mad...), so make sure you are good on that. The middle hole is 5.05mm, designed to fit over a 3/16" metal rod I had laying around from my other projects. Fit well with no wiggle room.

title: Judar's Wand from Magi
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I present to you a magical artifact owned by none other than the Magi of the Kou Empire, Judar!

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Designed to be printed with no supports, and on a small printer. It should be able to fit in most printers. I had the "Crest with spikes" print fail once because of a lack of bed adhesion (in the last 10 minutes, I'm not mad...), so make sure you are good on that. The middle hole is 5.05mm, designed to fit over a 3/16" metal rod I had laying around from my other projects. Fit well with no wiggle room.

Post printing processing consisted of light sanding on the parts that I could sand well. Used Bondo body filler to fill the larger holes and valleys. Started at 120 grit, then 2 coats of primer, sanded at 250 grit, primed, and sanded at 400. Parts were glued together with Krazy Glue then painted with a shiny silver metalic spray paint. The gem was painted with a gloss red spray paint. Whole thing got 2 coats of clear acrylic. The gem and arms holding it aren't glued, just held on by friction.

Print time was about 3 hours for all the pieces, one piece at a time. About 3-4 hours of sanding and painting. Not too bad at all.

description.text:
Hard seltzer koozie inspired by your favorite Friday afternoon podcast, A Mediocre Time with, uh.... what are their names again? Tod and Dave? Tim and Don? Something like that. Script "Tim & Don" on the koozie, not visible in the thumbnail.

Anyway, the can diameter is 57.2mm and the koozie inner diameter is 57.5mm. Scale as needed for your printer. Might be a good idea to do a test and stop it at about 25% to test fit a can.

Add a thicker, improved version that might actually even help keep a drink cool .

Resolution:

0.3mm is fine

Infill:

10% at most

text_size = 39

The Annelise Violin (aka. The Annie Fiddle)

I wanted to create a violin that reminded me of the old steel bridges found on the way to New Orleans, on the bayou roads. I also wanted to give the fingerboard a lighter, classical look. These features required me to add some breakaway supports, so you'll need your exacto.

This particular print takes advantage of a lot of mid-print color changes. Which require either a lot of watching or some .gcode editing (found online or ask me and I can post later). I hope you like it.

This design uses a standard violin bridge, allows for a standard shoulder rest and allows for a traditional style 3D printed chin rest (included and set up for screw on brackets).

If you prefer, I've also included blank pieces of the design in case you want to remix or go with the clean look.

Since the lower bout and waist of the violin can't be printed as one piece on a standard 8" printer, the waist parts screw on (so they can be replaced if broken or left out all together if you choose). You will likely have to print the lower bout at 45º in order to fit, with very little brim as it makes it too large to fit. Either way I can't wait to see what you make of it.

If you're looking for a nice way to display them, check out my Electric Violin Wall Hanger:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2575603

Oh and the parts are interchangeable with my other violin: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2122773

A big shout out to Stepan Ignatovich for the inspiration and original remix source of the neck.

In order to achieve the look I wanted and not have to paint the PLA, I had to be very careful not to sand or file any of the exposed areas, instead I used a small exacto knife to clean up edges. On this print I did decide to file the fingerboard AFTER screwing the neck pieces together. Gives it an even tighter seam than the exacto, but also a more matte finish.

Let me know if anything is missing.

Printing

I recommend printing one piece at a time. It's time consuming, but you'll want more control in the end. After a few attempts, only 3 pieces required supports in the end. The two violin waist pieces with the pipes required a bit of finagling with printing supports and cleaning. The bottom 2 parts of the neck had the coolest effect when printing flat, so I printed neck_part3 with supports (therefor the hidden under part where the tuning pegs screw in is not as smooth as the rest). The chin rest also of course requires supports to get that classic curve.

General Materials

Printed Parts - 8pcs your choice
Threaded Metal Rod M8 x 370mm

Violin Bridge - will need sanding like all bridges, but also flattening out of the feet
Violin Pickup and Preamp - for under bridge (easy to find on eBay or Amazon)
Guitar Tuners - 4pcs (2 left/2 right)
Shoulder Rest - Standard Type
Chin Rest Bracket - Standard Type
Violin Strings

Screws and Nuts

Screws:
M4 x 25mm socket cap - 9pcs
M4 x 15mm socket cap - 2pcs
M4 x 12mm socket cap - 2pcs
M4 x 50mm - 1pcs (philips or flat head)
M4 x 40mm - 2pcs (philips or flat head)
4/40 - 3/8" OR M3 x 8mm - 4pcs (for tuning pegs) matching WI's   
M2 x 10mm - 4pcs (Note: often provided with violin pickup)

Nuts:
M4 - 16pcs
M3 Brass Wood Screw Inserts for the tuners - 4pcs (likely need to drill out a bit for a smooth fit, brass is soft and will break if it has much resistance in the plastic)

Infill and Walls

I used a 20% with a mix of 4mm and 3mm thick walls to make sure it was solid enough to hold it's tuning and have a warm sound. But because that makes it fairly heavy compared to a classical acoustic (or carbon fiber electric) I am still looking for the right balance. If you make one, please comment with your settings and the outcome. Still pondering testing switching out the 370mm M8 Threaded Metal Rod with a carbon fiber rod or tube.

comments.text: Hey, one last question, i've got the piezo set, and i am a bit confused to how to install it, is it supposed to be installed under the  bridge like in the picture?, because if so, one would have to make a hole in the threaded rod.
comments.author: starkn

comments.text: Thanks for attaching the photo, it helped me figure out what's going on.  It appears that you're actually building the Mina Violin (which is my first violin) and not this one.  Though they have interchangeable parts.  But at the same time, I actually ran into the same problem as you, so I can relate.
comments.author: starkn

comments.text:
Hey, thank you for your insight, my first plan of action was of drilling through the threaded rod, but i went with your advice and drilled to the side, which seems to be doing the job given that the wire coming from the piezo is a bit offset to the side.
I picked th other part without really studying the general design thinking that those were the same.
comments.author: Jaxelsson

comments.text: Hey people, i printed this one, but i am wondering about the size, should i buy accessories comptaible with 3/4 or 4/4? Thanks.
comments.author: starkn

comments.text: This is definitely a full size (4/4) violin.  I have pondered making a smaller scale for my youngest, but have not yet had time.
comments.author: starkn

comments.text: Making this for a friend and I know little about instruments, I have spent several hours looking for the right product to make the electrics work but i've only confused myself deeply. Can you post a link or help me figure it out. I see this one is it right?
comments.author: adamm285

comments.text: Yes, that one should work fine.  There are two basic options that people seem to use; the BQLZR (your link) and the Silent EQ.  Both are also available on Amazon.  I used the latter one for both of mine, but I really don’t know that they are much different.  I suspect the electronics are very “similar” and they both are made in China.  There are of course pro-level options that one could look into, but I think you’ll be happy with these at least for starters.  There shouldn’t be much for you to be confused about (other than perhaps the internet sellers making information complicated).  Let me know if you still have questions and best of luck!  Looking forward to seeing your Make photos on here.
comments.author: adamm285

comments.text: Thank you that makes it crystal clear
comments.author: Jaxelsson

comments.text:
I don't play the Violin, so I'm sorry if my question seems a little stupid, but I'm making this for a friend and I really want to get it right.
I've finished the printing of all the parts (beautiful, buy the way) and at the end of the part labeled "neck_part2_steel_rafter2" there's a small raised line, should I cut that off and sand it down, or is that important? I see on the pics you posted that the line is not there, so thought I'd ask before I get busy with the sanding.
Still waiting for some more parts to arrive before final assembly, but once it's done I'll post some 'made' pics.
comments.author: bobbyboy75

comments.text:
Yes that should be cut off. It's just intended to help keep that edge square when printing. Also, after assembly and the neck being tightly screwed, I actually ended up filing/sanding down the fingerboard on this one to be perfectly smooth. The printer doesn't make it as smooth as a traditional ebony fingerboard. In my case the black PLA looked a lot like ebony after finely sanding.
Note: I personally don't paint mine as the paint could flake off, especially under the strings. I just use use an exacto. So I have tried not to sand many parts to keep the smooth color consistency of the PLA. Best of luck!
comments.author: bobbyboy75

comments.text:
Perfect! thanks for getting back to me.
I'll sand it down smooth, would covering the sanded area with a thin layer of epoxy effect the sound? was just thinking i'd like it to be smooth to look polished and epoxy would be an easy way to do that as well as not flaking like paint. I went with the same red and black as you did since it looks amazing.
comments.author: Jaxelsson

comments.text: Oh and thanks for the compliments, I designed these 2 for each of my daughters and they had a lot of input so I will pass it on.
comments.author: bobbyboy75

comments.text: I have not experimented with epoxy on any surfaces so I really can't say for sure.  What I can tell you is that the stronger the plastic the better it will hold up on the fingerboard.  As for polished, perhaps the body would look sharp that way but most violin fingerboard aren't, I think mostly because the strings will unpolish them pretty quick.  A matte surface that won't rub off is likely your best bet.
comments.author: bobbyboy75

comments.text: Ahh! I understand now, thank you so much for your help.
comments.author: Jaxelsson

comments.text: I don't suppose you could modify to take five strings, so that we can add the Viola C string?
comments.author: EngAl

comments.text: So I couldn't resist.  And I give you credit for challenging me. ;-)  I'm currently working on a 5 String Violin... stay tuned.
comments.author: EngAl

comments.text: Great stuff!. My wife says "Amazing" and is so excited.
comments.author: Jaxelsson

comments.text: Always nice to hear that people are enjoying my work!  Since she’s a player, does she have advice on how curved the base of the fingerboard should be?  I know most of it is in the curve of the bridge, but the fingerboard needs to match somewhat well.  Trying to figure out if 5 strings need A) an extension on the curve (same radius as 4 string which would result in 125% more bowing action), B) stretched out wider (requiring only more careful bowing or C) a curve somewhere in between.  Any advice/input will help.
comments.author: EngAl

comments.text: Now you have me thinking.  Basically it would be a viola and a violin in one.  I guess the only reason it would be called a 5 string violin instead of a 5 string viola is size...
comments.author: EngAl

comments.text:
It is definitely doable and I would encourage someone to try. Especially if you're a player with some experience with 5 string layout. Would simply require widening the neck (plus duplicating holes of course) and adjusting the body mount to accommodate it. Electronics for that would be a question I don't have the answer to yet.
Knowledge of 3D modelling or the interest in learning would be key of course. I mostly use the free version of SketchUp which isn't the best but it works. I'd love to attempt it but don't have the time at the moment. Let me know if you or someone attempts it. Curious.
comments.author: EngAl

comments.text:
Thank you for your response. They get called either 5 string Viola or Violin. I guess there may be a mixture of widening the neck and also placing the strings slightly closer together (not sure). There are some cheap ones available on the net. I would think that a slightly longer neck might be in order too.
It's not me who's the musician, as an Engineer I needed some culture so I married it. Wife teaches Violin, Viola and Piano. When I showed her your Violin, it was the key selling point for getting her over the line for me to buy a 3D printer. I do have the free Sketch-up, however I now use the free version of Fusion 360 as I found it more intuitive for me. Anyway I have already started printing your Violin and have the Body Parts done (PLA 15% Infill). I will post it when I eventually finish it. I have a Carbon Fibre Rod in the shed out back (6mm?) so I might consider making some mods. Otherwise I'll start with the steel Rod and then go from there later.
comments.author: Jaxelsson

comments.text: Cool! thanks for sharing. I really like the bridge inspiration.
comments.author: Kezat

comments.text: absolutely beautiful! No, profile pic is not of me.  I dont even play violin, but, man, if my printers build plate was big enough I would print this.!!
comments.author: Syntax2600

comments.text: Thanks!  Glad you like it.  Believe it or not, it fits (turned just slightly with a very small brim) on a standard i3 style printer.  I'm using a Monoprice Maker Select V2 which is 7.9".
comments.author: Syntax2600

comments.text: Did you use a fiberglass pole inside the violin or was the PVA able to withstand the string tension?
comments.author: Jaxelsson

comments.text: I've actually been meaning to try out fiberglass rods or tubes, but haven't felt like I needed to worry much about the weight yet.  The design (as in the notes) uses a steel threaded rod which definitely holds the strength.  The PLA plastic is definitely strong on its own and flexes much less than ABS would. Probably used more plastic than needed with the steel rod in mind.  I think if I made a bunch more I could figure out the right balance between plastic and either types of rods.

title: Indicator Mount for E3D hotend on D-Bot Printers.

description.text:
This is a slide-on Indicator Mount that fits on the D-Bot E3D Hotend mount. Made for a Harbor Freight Indicator. Two adjustment screws can be used in case your mount is slight smaller than mine. With this you can easily gets your bed level within .02mm or less. Once adjusted with the 3mm screws, the mount will just slide on and off. Enjoy !

Parts Needed:
1- 6mm x 25mm Bolt
1- 6mm Nut
2- 3mm x 8mm screws (Optional) (Will need to Thread the two holes with 3mmx.50mm Tap)
