print_settings.Notes:: Only the fan main body needs supports. I oriented the print so the supports were on the interior for appearance before I printed it.

title: HEPA Fume / Exhaust Fan w/ Filter

description.text:
Had a few messages on what I used to power the cabinet as well as the LED and fans. This is what I used and it has worked well.
http://amzn.to/2wnfhUy

I wanted a filter to fit what I needed on my in progress IKEA Lack Prusa enclosure. I plan on mounting this to the top of the enclosure to help cool and clean any ABS or other fumes. I will post some follow ups once the enclosure is done and the MK2S arrives.

Holes are 3mm threaded, I used a grommet I had laying around not sure what you will needs depends on what fan you use as well. But home depot is a good source for different sizes and needs. The fan pushes a ton of air but the HEPA filter slows the air flow down a great deal; I might just opt for a carbon filter mesh and cut it to size. The filter is press fit, the fan is as well and doesn't require any fasteners- there is a stop on the inside for the fan to bottom out against as well.

Print time: took about 12-13 hours for the main body and 1-2 hours each for the grills. However I printed mine at .15 with a 15% infill on the X-One.

Inspiration for enclosure came from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2150826 also the fan shrouds it included. Good work all the way around.

Amazon Parts Needed:
Fan: http://amzn.to/2pMKCwk
Filter: http://amzn.to/2qn9Iip
Black PLA Pro- http://amzn.to/2pMYMxx

Printed in eSUN PLA pro- love this stuff, its about all I sue now. Honestly you should give it a try if you have not.

QIDI X-One

No

Yes

.15 to .2

10% to 20%

Notes:

Only the fan main body needs supports. I oriented the print so the supports were on the interior for appearance before I printed it.

description.text: All Straight, Bank and Turn Templates for use with X-wing Miniatures tabletop game.

What do you do with old 3mm filament when all your printers are taking 1.75mm filament?

Well you could weave a basket! How about this?

The base of the basket is of course 3D-printed -- it consists of a ring, and a insert.
To build the basket:
1) cut 11 strings of 3mm filament, ca 40cm long. (at some point I though it should be an odd number for weaving, and then I chose a prime number)
2) print the ring fila-basket-11r.stl and one inset fila-basket-11i-s.stl -- from the latter, you can break away some tiny support towers at the bottom side. (the fila-basket-11i.stl file is without the supports, if the support fails for you).
3) There are two sets of holes in the ring. Insert one end of each string into one of the upper holes. If they have a lose fit, push further, use a pair of pliers to squeeze the end, then pull back.
4) take one string and loop it around to approximately the opposite side, and insert it in one of the lower holes.
5) take the next string, pull it under the first one, and insert it into the next hole.
6) take the next string, pull it under then above, then fix its end.
7) and so on. You alternate under and above all the way until the end.
8) the basket is probably not exactly round or not exactly equal height on your first attempt. Squeeze and stretch the pattern to make everything equal.
9) insert the hub. It should have a tight snap fit, and all the ends of the strings that stick through the holes should disappear in the grooves underneath.

Printer:

STARTT Tronxy xy100

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm and 3mm(!)

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I am printing with a0.2mm nozzle. This produces a raft that easily disintegrates and a better bottom area of the ring, where it rests on support. Support is not strictly needed for the ring, but depending on your printer, it might make a better or worse bottompart of the ring.

The hub has some extra 3mm diameter support pillars. So that it does not need any support.
You can break away the pillars before assembly.

print_settings.Notes:: screwcube()

description.text: Another "two parts go together to form a cube" puzzle. Best if printed in two colors.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Orient the model so that the face that looks like a letter "D" is face up, and it'll print without supports.

I find 33mm the perfect size of these, so consider scaling up 1.66x in your slicer.

I didn't take the time to make the scad file Customizable, so if the fit is too tight or too free for your system, you have no recourse but to edit the .scad file. Find the ff= value in two places in screwcube() and modify it. The helix is displaced away from the Z axis by this value, so the gap is equal to twice the value.

I was heavily inspired by RoCMP's design, but I somehow overlooked that there was a .scad file in their Thing, so I made my own from scratch. My design is asymmetrical, which I like because there's one more wrong way to assemble the Thing.

The basic idea is: cut a cube into two identical parts, in this case by using a helix to divide 3-dimensional space into two half-spaces.

One of the difficulties in producing this design is the way OpenSCAD treats polygons—nearby, near-collinear points are eliminated. It turns out that RoCMP works around this in a clever way, by scaling up the helix. But linear_extrude looks bad when it is extruding something with big flat faces. I didn't find this workaround, so I ended up reimplementing the moral equivalent of linear_extrude in OpenSCAD language itself which was certainly an adventure in its own right.

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend ABS for the print. I've tried PETG and HIPS, but it complicates post print processing. The model is best printed hole face side down. Supports shouldn't be needed.

description.text:
This is a phone holder ashtray for the Porsche 914. It's designed to accepted phone mounts made for air vents. It's a straight drop in for the factory ash tray. Instead of trying to solve the problem of the mount, this ash tray is more of a mount for a mount. It emulates the fitting pattern found on many mounts designed for air vents. It should work with any mount you find that claims to work on air vents. On the underside, there is a indentation designed to hold and pass-through a braided USB cable.
The cable seen can be found on Amazon.

The mounts seen in the photos can be found on amazon, but any mount for air vents should work. Mount 1 Mount 2

Printer Brand:

Zortrax

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.14mm

Infill:

Low

Notes:

I recommend ABS for the print. I've tried PETG and HIPS, but it complicates post print processing. The model is best printed hole face side down. Supports shouldn't be needed.

Post Processing to achieve a Great Finish

After printing, the model was sanded down with 240 grit, 320 grit and finally 400 grit. Then it was primed with Rust-Oleum Black Sandable Primer. More sanding with 400 grit sandpaper until all surface defects have been removed. Another layer of primer, then a final sand at 600 grit. Then a coat of SEM Trim Black paint is applied. Sand away any defects with 600 grit. Apply a final coat of the SEM paint.

print_settings.Notes:: printed the main body with the hole pointing to the sky, the cap with the flat back to the build surface.  Since i hunt primarily in the black of night and tend to drop things frequently, I printed in glow in the dark.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This is a ridiculously niche item; a pocket ammo case/dispenser designed specifically for the infamous Lyman collar button 45-70 round. The design allows the slugs to rest safely on rails, keeping unwanted pressure spread out across the stronger radius' of the bullet. The bullets wont slide around, they'll roll like little lead train cars, which pretty much eliminates any chance of deformation.

The cap fits very snug, so you don't need to worry about spilling all your ammo into your pockets- leaving you with shiny lint balls instead of ammunition. There are a few variations included, but the one printed in the photo seems to be the sturdiest. I've yet to print or test the picatinny rail variation so I expect it to have a few flaws.

I use these exclusively with my Airforce Texan 45 cal air rifle, and find that a convenient portable ammo storage solution is a must. Though my ammo is sized to .456 I believe I've left the gap wide enough to accommodate up to .459.

At the moment the case holds 8-9 shots, which is the precise amount of shots I get before needing to recharge the rifle. You could easily scale it or mesh mix it to hold far more. The rail guides that the slugs ride on would also allow for a pretty easy looped design if you are so inclined... I'm not.

If I ever manage to get my Texan back to shooting larger 400gn shots I will likely design more cases to fit, but for now this is what I'm using.

I hope this comes in handy for the other three people on the planet that shoot Lyman collar buttons with a 45 cal air rifle and also happen have a 3d printer. I suppose muzzle loaders may find this useful as well, but who knows.

I also recommend a few drops of lube into the case itself to keep everything shiny and slippery.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

title: 1mm Pushrod linkage keeper for RC plane
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I prefer not to double bend my pushrods because its difficult and potentially can break the control horns.
The Edge 540 designed by 3DLabprint is such a nice design with very tight movement of the control surfaces resulting in near zero backlash. In most cases this allows high speed control horn position settings and therefore no need for mechanical trimming - there is enough control on the transmitter.
But when I try and bend the 1mm pushrod wire, the second bend can result in damage etc.
Much better to have a linkage keeper like this one.

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The rather unorthodox print position is for these reasons:

  • if it sat upright in either position the strength would rely on bond strenght - not good
  • if it sat on the edge, the definition in the clip slot was not printing tight enough to hold securely to the pushrod, on my printer

description.text:
There is a new version of this! Thing# 2387397

Flight video: https://youtu.be/tWLh6Gt0URo
This is a great delta/ flying wing airplane. There is so much room inside for activities! The motor mount is designed to keep a 6 inch (or 5in) prop above the ground so that you can smoothly land on anything. There is a slight downward angle to keep the thrust line through the center of gravity of the plane. The only printable part is the motor mount and the controls horns and throw gauges. The rest of the plane is made from hot glue and sturdy foam board (not dollar tree foam board). I get mine at AC Moore. You can usually find a 40% off one item coupon if you look on their website. I have included a sketchup files. You can use the the box wing.skp files to take measurement of the airframe (mm are actually inches). Sketchup is free btw. It has a 28 inch wing span. Each elevon is 2x11 inches. The CG is 9.25 inches from the nose. You can move it farther back after you get the flight controller working.

Hardware:
two 9g servos (you can get metal gear servos on banggood for about $2 each)
20A ESC (make sure its not OPTO, those need a separate BEC)
2306 2150kv motor (any mini quad motor will work)
6x4.5 Prop
CM703 Redcon receiver (If you use Spektrum, check these cheap DSM2/ DSMX receivers on banggood)
Battery 1000mAh to 5200mAh 3 cell
CC3D flight controller (I included the CC3D tuning numbers)

The CC3D flight controller is cheap and powerful!

Update 5/2/17: I tried to abort a landing by punching it and pulling up, but I did not have enough altitude. It hit the ground with full power still applied. This broke the motor mount at the skinny part below the 4 mounting hole. (Weak point, duh). I made a stronger version called "box wing mm 2"). It also has a wider foot print.

Update 5/9/17: I now prefer to fly fpv without a flight controller. There is much less room for center of gravity error without the flight controller, but the plane is more stable at speed. I have dialed in the throws and center of gravity. There should be 5mm of reflex on the elevons. Full up on each elevon (pitch and roll together) should be 25 degrees. Full down (pitch and roll together) should be 20 degrees. I have added two throw gauges. I will make very detailed plans soon.

Printer:

Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal

Infill:

70%

Tray

title: Bodhi Leaf with Stem Hole for Earring/Necklace Ring

description.text:
To create this laser cut Bodhi leaf, I found an image of a Bodhi leaf on Pixabay, sent it through the Live Trace in Adobe Illustrator, and hand-vectorized the outline. I added a stem with a hole to that outline.

For the necklace, I cut out three leafs from 1/8" plywood and glued them together - the 2 outside leaves were etched, and the inner one was just the outline with the stem.

I suggest these improvements on my design: 1) 3/8" is thick! just cut 1 or 2 leaves, 2) thicken the end of the bodhi leaf so that it's less fragile - the wood can splinter easily down there.

remixed_from.author: sailorpete
remixed_from.title: Root 3 CNC multitool router 3D printed parts

description.text:
A supersized Root2cnc.

I wanted to build the Root2.1 with a work area of 1200 x 1200 and judging by comments on Facebook, there would be issues with flex of the 25x25mm side rails so I redrew the parts for 40x40mm X and Y rails.

I am using steel square tube for the rails.
Printed in PETG everything fitted together well.

Note I have not included any holes in the Z axis backing plate as there seems to be a huge variation in Z axis layouts.
.
All other parts lot listed here are as per the original Root2.1

Edit: Added Y Gantry motion link.

18 May, 2017. Replaced the dxf files for the wood parts with stl's as the dxf's were not reproducing well in freecad. I also added a stl for the x axis rear panel. (Note: they are labelled Z carraige).

2 June, 2017. Added 8mm spacers for the Y gantry nema23, Y gantry motion link 8mm spacer and Y gantry bearing 8mm spacers. These are to move the pulleys out 8mm so they line up with the Y axis bar mounts better. I also added a couple of photo's of the build so far. For the drive shaft between the left and right Y motors, I used some 20mm allow machine bar, (because that's what I had laying around), and drilled each end to insert 8mm steel stub axles fastened with grub screws. This is to reduce the possibility of torsional "wind up" if you where to use 8mm steel across the entire width of the machine.

9 June, 2017. Added a dxf drawing for the front Z axis plate with holes for the linear guides. The holes are 25mm apart and the two rows are 100mm apart.
EDIT: dxf file was not showing all the holes, use the stl instead.

12 December, 2017. Added a few more photos. I have taken it off the "Work in progress" status because I am happy with the machine as it stands.
I only have a dremel mounted as a spindle at the moment so routing aluminium is SSSLLLOOOWWW but it does do it.
I intend to set up the plasma cutter in the next few weeks.

More info on the rootcnc forum here.
https://rootcnc.com/forums/topic/a-1200x1200mm-root2-1-or-3-with-40x40-rails/#post-1082

https://youtu.be/4bUiL51nPEU

comments.text: I will use 16mm round stainless steel bars for the z axis.The mounting for the bars to the plates will be 3d printed, also the housings for the open linear bearings.I know thats not a good idea but this is how i will do it, i hope it works.
comments.author: lefteris15

comments.text:
16mm bars will be super rigid.
On my machine I have bronze bushes on the z axis and as close together as they are, it is a very rigid assembly.
I think linear bearings are not as rigid as bushes but spacing them 68mm apart will certainly be rigid enough I would think.
Well done.
comments.author: lefteris15

comments.text: Hello,
comments.author: lefteris15

comments.text:
I just finished rebuilding my Z axis and have 135mm travel. Not a lot for a mill but plenty for a plasma cutter.
Made my first plasma cuts with the 40x40 root2cnc today. Works a treat. I must remember to take a video next time.
If you extend your steel support table frame up to increase the height of the gantry over the bed as I did, you get a more rigid machine than if you were to make longer or extend "Y axis bar mount".
Keep in mind though that pressure on the cutting tool while lowered well below the normal bed level will put increased load on the machine and you MAY experience considerable flexing.
comments.author: lefteris15

There seems to be as many variations on the Z axis construction as there are machines built. It seems like a very personal thing.
I would be happy to draw something for you if you list the parts you are going to use.

description.text:
Made this small handle so i can use the bits for my electric screwdriver as a regular screwdriver. also, you can stick 3 bits into the end of the handle so it can be a bit holder too.
Also added a small socket for a 5mm neodyum magnet for keeping the bit in place while in use.
Keep in mind that i made this for my hex driver bits with 3mm shaft, so it might need to be modified slightly for your needs. Also, you might have to scale it, depending on your printer's accuraci, and setup. +/- 1-2% in scale, to find your optimal fit for your bits.

print_settings.Notes:: I used Cura to produce the Gcode. Layer height .2mm, shell thickness .4mm, bottom/top thicknes .6mm. I set the support type to lines at 10% and it printed the overhanging surface around the top very well. Supports came away easily needing only very minor touch up with a hobby knife.

description.text:
This is my design based on the Biocube factory filter tray. It lets you use your own DLS or other material as desired. The filter packs sold for the Biocube become clogged easily with debris. I usually can't get even one month out of one. So I took one apart to try to salvage the shell, only to find there were vertical walls separating 4 chambers of the drip tray. This would not allow water to flow evenly throughout the surface of the tray. So I decided to design my own. This one follows the dimensions of the original, but has a flat bottom with a grid of 3mm holes to allow water to drip freely across the entire surface. And the single chamber makes it easy to cut and replace a single piece of DLS or foam to trap particles. The media chamber is 60mm x 180mm x 12mm deep.

I have a few other ideas for things to make for this aquarium. If you find this one useful, or have any questions, please let me know.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used Cura to produce the Gcode. Layer height .2mm, shell thickness .4mm, bottom/top thicknes .6mm. I set the support type to lines at 10% and it printed the overhanging surface around the top very well. Supports came away easily needing only very minor touch up with a hobby knife.

comments.text: If this is going in a saltwater aquarium, do not print it in PLA. PLA degrades in saltwater very quickly.

description.text: For fix the broken USB cord

print_settings.Notes:: Super easy to print.

description.text:
I was sick cords slipping off my desk and nightstand, so I designed yet another cable holder! This one is highly functional and works very well.

It has ten pennies inside for weight. Just print along with the two caps, press five pennies into each side then snap on the caps! Works great for USB cables, speaker cables, power cords and more.

The radius of the penny hole as well as the tolerance for the cap snap fit have been tuned for my printer, so scale the parts accordingly if you're having problems with fit. The model can also be scaled to accommodate other coins, but keep in mind the cable slot size will change as well. It works fantastically for me, but it might be useful to add rubber pads to the feet for some situations.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Super easy to print.
The pulley that lets you use a rope to extend the ladder broke. I measured the broken one, made one in TinkerCAD and printed it and my ladder is 100% again.

remixed_from.title: Anycubic Kossel Plus Heated Bed Clips

title: Anycubic Plus bed clip for 240mm bed and glass

description.text:
JamesWhite made a great bed mount that surpassed the original 6 mounting blocks that were provided with the Anycubic Linear Plus Kit. My version (03/21/2017) came with a 240mm aluminum heated build platform and 240mm glass plate. I just knocked down the tab a bit with Sketchup so they'd both fit without sitting higher. Admittedly, I don't have any skills with design or these cad apps, so this is just a tweak.

If one were so inclined, adding a few bulges or tangs to the last 1-1.25mm at the top would likely hold the glass in place without the need for the top clips. I don't think this would even protrude too far from the edge, just far enough to put a touch of pressure on the glass.

Thanks, JamesWhite.

Update 5/3/2017
Added those tangs and printed them. My first attempt at this resulted in me closing the bolt holes somehow..."I'm a newb award winner".

Is the plate secured in place? Yup.
Necessary? Probably not.
Does it look professional? Nope.
Will it affect anything else? Not unless you are printing on the last .25mm of the 240mm glass plate.
Downsides? You need to loosen one side to remove the glass build plate.

Holdoor has the tangs.

Anycubic Linear Plus

Doesn't Matter

30%

Notes:

description.text:
This is a slight remix of poor_red_neck's Lithophane Night Light adapter. I used his guide to create mine. I used all of the same settings as him, except in the model settings on http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ I set the curve to 160. This makes the lithophane wrap around the light more.

I remixed his adapter, adding more curve to fit the new shape of the lithophane as well as adding a bit of support to the wings that slide around the light.

You will have to use meshmixer (or some other software) to combine the .stl of the lithophane generated by the site above with the adapter provided here. Please see poor_red_neck's original post for details.

I printed in ABS and am using an incandescent bulb night light. The bulbs are only 7W so they don't get hot enough to worry about softening the print, even if PLA was used. You can touch the bulbs directly and they are barely warm to the touch. I think the incandescent bulbs spread the light better than the LED versions, and are a warmer light.

UPDATE:

I realized after making a few of these, that using a photo with a different width may result in a lithophane that doesn't fit this adapter. So, I came up with a way to create an adapter for a photo of any size. I wrote an instructable as well as made an accompanying video describing the process. Check it out if you're interested. http://www.instructables.com/id/Lithophane-Night-Light/

comments.text: Awesome! I like the remix alot better than my own! I had to make these for a gift for some family members and whipped it up in 123D as quick as I could but it definitely needed refining.
comments.author: poor_red_neck

comments.text: Thanks!! I've had the idea rattling around in my head since the first time I saw a lithophane. I typically use Sketchup to model things, but trying to import the .stl of the litho from 3dp.rocks to add a base never quite worked out for me. A coworker asked me if I could make these so I decided to try again when I stumbled upon your adapter and guide. I hadn't used meshmixer and couldn't have done it without your guide, so for that I thank you. And I completely understand not finding the time for videos. I've shot 2-3 videos that I haven't had a chance to edit yet...
comments.author: poor_red_neck

description.text:
I had never heard of "lithophanes" before seeing them here on Thingiverse. Having found them, and having printed several myself, these things are amazing! This is my contribution to this awesome art form - the (in)famous Princess Leia slave scene in the Jabba the Hutt throne room. I couldn't decide which pose looked better, so I did both.

Ever since I discovered 3d printing, I have been searching high and low for a good, high quality model of this scene. If anyone has a model, or knows where I can find one... PLEASE let me know!

-=[ UPDATE ]=-

So, ummmmm.... yeah... It seems I accidentally created these with the image settings set to "negative." I have uploaded the corrected version (as _v2). Anyone care to tell me why there would be a "negative" setting on a lithophane creator?!

This was rendered via the 3dp.rocks/lithophane web site.

_v2 was rendered directly in Cura 2.5

comments.text: Printing it in Negative, when held up to light turns it into a positive, that's how these are meant to work, there are a ton of helpful you tubes on these.
comments.author: Vk6ffar

comments.text: Not exactly. You want the image to be a positive and when you slice that, you instruct the slicer to make the dark areas higher than the light areas. If you start with a negative image, then it looks like a 35mm negative when viewed from the front with a backlit source. The second photo here, of the printed litho, was printed using the corrected file, created from a positive source image. Print both and you'll see the difference.
comments.author: Vk6ffar

title: Double Pendulum Fidget Spinner Toy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 5/3/17 : I added a base that you can place this spinner on. It lets this become more of a desk toy than a handheld toy. Since spinning the pendulum causes a lot of side-to-side momentum, I had to use weights in the bottom of the base. The weights I used were 1/2 oz. wheel weights from harbor freight. I fit 1 lb. worth of those weights in the base and with some rubber feet on the bottom, it hardly moves when spinning it.

This is a double pendulum fidget toy I designed. I saw plenty of desktop sized double pendulums online and, while I could have made one that size, I wanted to make one that I could carry around with me. Recently with fidget spinners becoming popular, I found myself having a box full of 608 bearings. With those I made a fun toy that I find myself going too more often than my fidget spinner now.

Here is a short clip showing how this spinner works.

Here is a clip showing the spinner on the base.

If you don't have a 3D printed but still want my design, please consider checking out my etsy page.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Assembly

Print out 1 long arm, 1 short arm, 1 washer, 1 long screw, 2 short screws, and 3 nuts. Assembly is very simple. This uses 4 608 skate bearings. Press the bearings into the openings on the arms. The short screw caps go on the end bearings and the long screw cap goes in the center through both bearings. Also, between the two center bearings, place the washer. This will keep the to arms separated just enough so there's no friction when spinning the toy. The base should be printed upside down so no supports are needed. Also the base arm was designed to press fit into the base. You may or may not need to scale the arm a couple percent depending on your printer's tolerance.
